title: 110_hr6808
content: The Act is titled the "Presidential Commission to Study the Culture and Glorification of Violence in America Act." Congress finds that violence in the United States may be fueled by various factors such as the media, psychological stress, the school system, gun regulations, and economic characteristics. In 2005, there were 1,823,400 serious violent crimes and 419,640 firearm-related incidents. Teens and young adults have the highest rates of violent crime, with 28 percent of school students ages 12-18 reporting being bullied. The incarceration rate has been increasing since the 1980s, with over half of the national prison population being convicted of a violent offense. According to various studies, economic frustration drives criminal behavior and hinders deterrence efforts. Unemployment has risen, particularly among teenagers, young adults, and African Americans. Exposure to media violence can lead to increased acceptance of violence. Exposure to media violence can increase acceptance of violence, glamorize weapons, and contribute to aggressive behavior. A commission called the Presidential Commission to Study the Culture and Glorification of Violence in America is established to investigate the impact of media violence on society. The Commission established will examine the glorification of violence, psychological factors, media's role, economic frustration, access to firearms, school system's role in preventing violence, and make recommendations to address the issue in the United States. The Commission established will examine factors contributing to violence in the United States and make recommendations. The Commission, composed of 16 members appointed by various leaders, must have special knowledge or experience in violence-related issues, including sociologists, psychologists, clergy, law enforcement officials, victims of violence, and representatives from media and entertainment industries. The Commission, composed of 16 members with expertise in violence-related issues, must not consider political affiliation in appointments. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled as per original appointment, and they do not receive pay. Travel expenses are covered, and a quorum of eight members is needed for business. The Commission, consisting of 16 members with expertise in violence-related issues, appoints a Chairperson and holds meetings as needed. SEC. 6. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairperson appoints Commission personnel and follows certain civil service laws for appointments and pay rates. Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Commission. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to carry out its duties. It can delegate authority to members or agencies and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission has the authority to contract with government or private agencies for supplies or services without following certain statutes. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress within one year of all members being appointed, detailing their findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. Any spending authority authorized by the Act will only be effective as provided in appropriations Acts.
